text: Your Wednesday Evening BriefingHere’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
The Modern Love PodcastSometimes marriage requires sound and fury.
The Book Review PodcastKerri Greenidge on Black resistance before the Civil War; Neal Gabler on Edward Kennedy.
How Trump Has Jeopardized Stimulus ReliefPresident Trump’s demand that Congress amend a giant coronavirus relief bill has raised the unexpected prospect that help may no longer be days away.
Trump Vetoes Defense Spending BillPresident Trump vetoed a military policy bill that had bipartisan approval, setting up what could be the first veto override of his presidency.

New Signs of Economic Distress Emerge as Trump Imperils Aid DealA decline in consumer income and spending poses a further challenge to the recovery as jobless claims remain high and benefits approach a cutoff.
The Year the Fed Changed ForeverJerome Powell’s central bank slashed rates, bought bonds in huge sums and rolled out never-before-tried loan programs. A backlash has already begun.
Even with the prospect of new federal aid, many Americans face a Christmas season of tough choices.
A President Unhappy, Unleashed and UnpredictablePresident Trump remains the most powerful man in the world, but powerless to achieve what he most wants: to avoid leaving office as a loser.

Blackwater’s Bullets Scarred Iraqis. Trump’s Pardon Renewed the Pain.Iraqi witnesses against Blackwater guards were promised justice after a mass killing in 2007. “They proved to me it was just theater,” one said.
Pfizer Seals Deal With U.S. for 100 Million More Vaccine DosesThe company agreed to deliver the additional doses of its coronavirus vaccine by the end of July, helping address a looming shortage.

Instead of a Mad Dash for Trump’s ‘Cure,’ Antibody Drugs Are Going UnusedDespite their promise, the treatments have been slowed by testing lags, overwhelmed hospitals and a perception they are only for well-connected people.

The Great ReadIt’s Peak Season for Tamales in Los AngelesMany of the city’s tamaleras — makers of tamales — are pressing on because the food, along with the cultures and microeconomies it sustains, is essential.
The Lives They LivedWe remember some of the artists, innovators and thinkers we lost in the past year.
On the podcast, Brian Thompson plays an earnest, eager naïf who regards himself as an intrepid seeker of truth. Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times
A Maine Paper Mill’s Unexpected Savior: ChinaA battered New England mill town greeted the new owner of its factory — one of the richest tycoons in China.
The Editorial BoardTrump Corrupted the Presidential Pardon. Biden Must Repair It.There are clear ways to reform the pardon process to work as the founders intended.

George Clooney on ‘The Midnight Sky’ and Donald TrumpHis new movie is on Netflix, but the actor-director says theaters won’t go away and Hollywood will be fine. He’s not so sure about Washington.
Want the Good Life? This Philosopher Suggests Learning From CatsIn “Feline Philosophy,” John Gray concedes that we “cannot know what it is like to be a cat,” but that doesn’t stop him from trying.
